author: booklearner
content:
Anyone aware of a resource covering a sequence to follow when reading the specs (both execution and consensus)? I'm wanting to grok client implementation details but unsure where/how to start with the specs. Where do you start _before_ you start reading the changes proposed in the fork specifications?

If such a resource does not exist, any value in working on something along the lines of a "client implementers guide"?

author: timbeiko
content: <@973581740734050334> I'd recommend something like https://benjaminion.xyz/eth2-annotated-spec/#design-goals as an entry point for the consensus layer.

author: timbeiko
content: A lot of EL "intro" stuff is wildly out of date, but this might be a good entry point. I'd just caution against assuming things still work the exact same way, and you can likely assume that the older the doc you are looking at is, the less accurate any "future predictions" are ðŸ™‚ https://ethereum.org/en/whitepaper/

author: booklearner
content: Awesome, annotated spec looks great! Thanks for sharing the links ðŸ™‚

author: timbeiko
content:
If you ever feel ambitious, a team is working on an EL spec but there is no annotated version: https://github.com/ethereum/execution-specs#consensus-specification-work-in-progress

Annotating that similarly to the CL annotated ones would be a great learning exercise that's super valuable to the community

author: timbeiko
content: Actually, it seems like the EL spec has a fair amount of context/notes, so probably submitting PRs to that to extend the annotations would be more valuable than starting one from scratch like on the CL side ðŸ™‚
